data.abstract: This protocol describes the procedure to isolate viral DNA from AAV-transfected tissue and prepare it for next-generation sequencing.
title: Library tissue handling, viral DNA extraction, and NGS sample preparation v2

data.abstract: This protocol describes the procedure to isolate viral DNA from AAV-transfected tissue and prepare it for next-generation sequencing.
title: Library tissue handling, viral DNA extraction, and NGS sample preparation v1

data.abstract: This NGS workflow describes how to prepare libraries from total RNA with a rRNA depletion step to increase the yield of non-host RNA transcripts. This workflow was initially designed with the aim of generating full-length hepaciviruses, but can also be used for sequencing any other RNA viral sequences or RNA-related metagenomes.
title: NGS workflow with rRNA depletion for viral RNA sequencing from animal tissue specimens v1

data.abstract: This chapter argues that viruses are at a major disadvantage in the task of reproducing themselves compared with higher forms of life. The latter all multiply by some form of fission, which ensures that the daughter cells start their existence with a full complement of genetic information, along with the enzymes necessary to replicate and catalyse the synthesis of new proteins. A virus, on the other hand, depends on the machinery of a cell. It enters the cell with nothing but its own genome, a molecule of nucleic acid that may encode for only twenty or so genes compared with 30,000 genes for a mammalian cell. The chapter explains that viruses rely heavily on the host cell for the materials they need for reproduction involving many cellular proteins and cell pathways. It shows why the replication of viruses is more complicated in some respects than that of other micro-organisms.
title: Viral replication and genetics
Detection and Quantification of Influenza Virus Defective Viral Genomes from NGS Datasets Obtained after RT or RT-PCR Product Sequencing

data.abstract: This chapter focuses on the control of viral diseases by immunization. It discusses the germ theory of disease, which was accepted in the late nineteenth century and led to the development of concepts of immunity, which made it possible to develop the scientific framework for the practice of immunization against microbial diseases. Vaccines contain what in modern terminology are virus proteins with antigenic areas called epitopes, which induce both B-cell and T-cell immunity. The chapter refers to vaccine-induced immunity that may last several years or a lifetime and explains that the ability to make these long-term responses is mediated by memory cells. The first vaccines to be prepared in the laboratory were those against smallpox and rabies. The chapter reviews other milestones of virus vaccine development, such as the attenuated yellow fever (YF) vaccine manufactured from infected chick embryos.
title: Control of viral diseases by immunization
original-title: Control of viral diseases by immunization
